form.preferredDefinition: A brief set of self-administered physical and medical questions used to determine if the person needs to visit a doctor or fitness expert prior to an increase in physical activity.

question.questionText: Has your doctor ever said that you have a heart condition OR high blood pressure? (physicalactivity_readiness_generalhealth_1)
Do you feel pain in your chest at rest, during the daily activities of living, OR when you do physical activity? (physicalactivity_readiness_generalhealth_2)

Do you lose balance because of dizziness OR have you lost consciousness in the last 12 months? Please answer NO if your dizziness was associated with over-breathing (including during vigorous exercise). (physicalactivity_readiness_generalhealth_3)
Have you ever been diagnosed with another chronic medical condition (other than heart disease or high blood pressure)? (physicalactivity_readiness_generalhealth_4)
Are you currently taking prescribed medications for a chronic medical condition? (physicalactivity_readiness_generalhealth_5)

Do you have a bone or joint problem that could be made worse by becoming more physically active? Please answer NO if you had a joint problem in the past, but it does not limit your current ability to be physically active. For example, knee, ankle, shoulder or other. (physicalactivity_readiness_generalhealth_6)
Has your doctor ever said that you should only do medically supervised physical activity? (physicalactivity_readiness_generalhealth_7)
Do you have arthritis, osteoporosis, or back problems? (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_1)

Do you have difficulty controlling your condition with medications or other physician-prescribed therapies? (Answer NO if you are not currently taking medications or other treatments) (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_1a)

Do you have joint problems causing pain, a recent fracture or fracture caused by osteoporosis or cancer, displaced vertebra (e.g., spondylolisthesis), and/ or spondylolysis/pars defect (a crack in the bony ring on the back of the spinal column)? (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_1b)
Have you had steroid injections or taken steroid tablets regularly for more than 3 months? (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_1c)
Do you have Cancer of any kind? (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_2)
Does your cancer diagnosis include any of the following types: lung/bronchogenic, multiple myeloma (cancer of plasma cells), head, and neck? (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_2a)
Are you currently receiving cancer therapy (such as chemotherapy or radiotherapy)? (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_2b)

Do you have Heart Disease or Cardiovascular Disease? This includes Coronary Artery Disease, High Blood Pressure, Heart Failure, Diagnosed Abnormality of Heart Rhythm (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_3)

Do you have difficulty controlling your condition with medications or other physician-prescribed therapies? (Answer NO if you are not currently taking medications or other treatments) (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_3a)
Do you have an irregular heart beat that requires medical management? (e.g. atrial fibrillation, premature ventricular contraction) (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_3b)
Do you have chronic heart failure? (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_3c)

Do you have a resting blood pressure equal to or greater than 160/90 mmHg with or without medication? (Answer YES if you do not know your resting blood pressure) (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_3d)
Do you have diagnosed coronary artery (cardiovascular) disease and have not participated in regular physical activity in the last 2 months? (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_3e)
Do you have any Metabolic Conditions? This includes Type 1 Diabetes, Type 2 Diabetes, Pre-Diabetes (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_4)
Is your blood sugar often above 13.0 mmol/L? (Answer YES if you are not sure) (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_4a)

Do you have any signs or symptoms of diabetes complications such as heart or vascular disease and/or complications affecting your eyes, kidneys, and the sensation in your toes and feet? (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_4b)
Do you have other metabolic conditions (such as thyroid disorders, pregnancyrelated diabetes, chronic kidney disease, liver problems)? (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_4c)

Do you have any Mental Health Problems or Learning Difficulties? This includes Alzheimer?, Dementia, Depression, Anxiety Disorder, Eating Disorder, Psychotic Disorder, Intellectual Disability, Down Syndrome) (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_5)

Do you have difficulty controlling your condition with medications or other physician-prescribed therapies? (Answer NO if you are not currently taking medications or other treatments) (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_5a)
Do you also have back problems affecting nerves or muscles? (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_5b)
Do you have a Respiratory Disease? This includes Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease, Asthma, Pulmonary High Blood Pressure (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_6)

Do you have difficulty controlling your condition with medications or other physician-prescribed therapies? (Answer NO if you are not currently taking medications or other treatments) (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_6a)
Has your doctor ever said your blood oxygen level is low at rest or during exercise and/or that you require supplemental oxygen therapy? (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_6b)

If asthmatic, do you currently have symptoms of chest tightness, wheezing, laboured breathing, consistent cough (more than 2 days/week), or have you used your rescue medication more than twice in the last week? (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_6c)
Has your doctor ever said you have high blood pressure in the blood vessels of your lungs? (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_6d)
Do you have a Spinal Cord Injury? This includes Tetraplegia and Paraplegia (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_7)

Do you have difficulty controlling your condition with medications or other physician-prescribed therapies? (Answer NO if you are not currently taking medications or other treatments) (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_7a)
Do you commonly exhibit low resting blood pressure significant enough to cause dizziness, light-headedness, and/or fainting? (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_7b)
Has your physician indicated that you exhibit sudden bouts of high blood pressure (known as Autonomic Dysreflexia)? (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_7c)
Have you had a Stroke? This includes Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA) or Cerebrovascular Event (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_8)

Do you have difficulty controlling your condition with medications or other physician-prescribed therapies? (Answer NO if you are not currently taking medications or other treatments) (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_8a)
Do you have any impairment in walking or mobility? (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_8b)
Have you experienced a stroke or impairment in nerves or muscles in the past 6 months? (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_8c)
Do you have any other medical condition not listed above or do you live with two chronic conditions? (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_9)

Have you experienced a blackout, fainted, or lost consciousness as a result of a head injury within the last 12 months OR have you had a diagnosed concussion within the last 12 months? (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_9a)
Do you have a medical condition that is not listed (such as epilepsy, neurological conditions, kidney problems)? (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_9b)
Do you currently live with two chronic conditions? (physicalactivity_readiness_chronic_medicalconditions_9c)
What is the subject's name? (physicalactivity_readiness_name)
What is today's date? (physicalactivity_readiness_date)

form.preferredDefinition: A standard liver panel is comprised of the following bioassays that are performed on refrigerated serum or plasma: alanine aminotransferase (ALT), aspartate aminotransferase (AST), alkaline phosphatase (ALP), bilirubin, albumin, total protein, and gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT).

headerInstruction.text: Persons will be excluded from this component if they: *Report that they have hemophilia; or *Report that they have received cancer chemotherapy in the last 4 weeks.

question.questionText: Do you have hemophilia? (pxt190801_hemophilia)
Have you received cancer chemotherapy in the past four weeks or do you anticipate such therapy in the next four weeks? (pxt190801_chemotherapy)
Please mark reason for exclusion (pxt190801_exclusion_criteria)

validValue.meaningText: Received cancer chemotherapy in the last 4 weeks
validValue.description: Received cancer chemotherapy in the last 4 weeks

question.questionText: Venipuncture Procedures: Please review chapter 4 of the Laboratory Procedures Manual from the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey 2007-2008 for a full description of phlebotomy procedures: 2007-2008 NHANES laboratory procedures manual .Venipuncture should generally be performed using the median cubital, cephalic, or basilic veins in the left arm unless this arm is unsuitable. If the veins in the left arm are unsuitable, look for suitable veins on the right arm. If the veins in the antecubital space on both arms are not suitable, then look for veins in the forearm or dorsal side of the hand on the left arm/hand and then the right arm/hand. Note from the Gastrointestinal Working Group: Blood should be collected in an appropriate 5- or 10-mL red-top tube. (venip_proc_liver)
Was blood drawn? (pxt190801_blood_draw_done)
Was full amount obtained? (pxt190801_blood_draw_sample)
Record any comments about the blood draw, including any reasons for the tube not being drawn according to the protocol. (pxt190801_blood_draw_comments)
Record comments to describe the sample during processing: (pxt190801_sample_comments)

protocol.preferredDefinition: A standard liver panel is comprised of the following bioassays that are performed on refrigerated serum or plasma: alanine aminotransferase (ALT), aspartate aminotransferase (AST), alkaline phosphatase (ALP), bilirubin, albumin, total protein, and gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT).

form.longName: PhenX PX220704 - Disease Progression And Regression Adult
form.preferredDefinition: The Newcastle Paediatric Mitochondrial Disease Scale (NPMDS) and the Newcastle Mitochondrial Disease Adult Scale (NMDAS) can be used to evaluate the progression of mitochondrial disease. There are three versions of the NPMDS, each for a specific age range (0-24 months, 2-11 years, and 12-18 years). The NMDAS is for adult patients over 16 years. The investigators from Newcastle University recommend that if the child experiences early onset of a mitochondrial disease in childhood, the NPMDS 12-18 year scale should be used. If an adolescent experiences onset of a mitochondrial disease, the investigators recommend switching to the NMDAS scale at 16 years. The aim of the scales is to allow for standardization of patient assessment and to improve accurate data collection. The scales are composed of multiple domains: Current Function, System Specific Involvement, Current Clinical Assessment, and Quality of Life. Almost all questions provide a score which ranges from 0-3, with the following representations: 0 is normal, 1 is mild, 2 is moderate, and 3 is severe. Examples of the severity for each question are provided. Depending on the domain, the questions are either self- or interviewer-administrated, based on a providers clinical assessment or medical records. There is a manual for each scale, which details the administration, process, and scoring instructions.

headerInstruction.text: The Newcastle Mitochondrial Disease Adult Scale (NMDAS)

question.questionText: Full Name (mitochondrial_disease_adult_name)
Date of Birth (mitochondrial_disease_adult_dob)
Today's Date (mitochondrial_disease_adult_date)
Height (mitochondrial_disease_adult_height)
Forced Vital Capacity - 1st attempt (mitochondrial_disease_adult_fvc1)
Forced Vital Capacity - 2nd attempt (mitochondrial_disease_adult_fvc2)
Forced Vital Capacity - 3rd attempt (mitochondrial_disease_adult_fvc3)

Section I- Current Function. Rate function over the preceding 4 week period, according to patient and/or caregiver interview only. The clinician's subjective judgement of functional ability should not be taken into account. (section_i_220704)
1. Rate function over the preceding 4 week period, according to patient and/or caregiver interview only. - Vision usual glasses or contact lenses (mitochondrial_disease_adult_current_vision)

validValue.meaningText: 1. No functional impairment but aware of worsened acuities.
validValue.description: 1. No functional impairment but aware of worsened acuities.

validValue.meaningText: 2. Mild - difficulty with small print or text on television.
validValue.description: 2. Mild - difficulty with small print or text on television.

validValue.meaningText: 3. Moderate - difficulty outside the home (eg bus numbers, road signs or shopping).
validValue.description: 3. Moderate - difficulty outside the home (eg bus numbers, road signs or shopping).

validValue.meaningText: 5. Unable to navigate without help (eg carer, dog, cane).
validValue.description: 5. Unable to navigate without help (eg carer, dog, cane).

question.questionText: 2. Rate function over the preceding 4 week period, according to patient and/or caregiver interview only. - Hearing with or without hearing aid (mitochondrial_disease_adult_current_hearing)

validValue.meaningText: 1. No communication problems but aware of tinnitus or deterioration from prior 'normal hearing.
validValue.description: 1. No communication problems but aware of tinnitus or deterioration from prior 'normal hearing.

validValue.meaningText: 2. Mild deafness (eg missing words in presence of background noise). Fully corrected with hearing aid.
validValue.description: 2. Mild deafness (eg missing words in presence of background noise). Fully corrected with hearing aid.

validValue.meaningText: 3. Moderate deafness (eg regularly requiring repetition). Not fully corrected with hearing aid.
validValue.description: 3. Moderate deafness (eg regularly requiring repetition). Not fully corrected with hearing aid.

validValue.meaningText: 4. Severe deafness - poor hearing even with aid (see 3 above).
validValue.description: 4. Severe deafness - poor hearing even with aid (see 3 above).

validValue.meaningText: 5. End stage - virtually no hearing despite aid. Relies heavily on non-verbal communication (eg lip reading) or has cochlear implant
validValue.description: 5. End stage - virtually no hearing despite aid. Relies heavily on non-verbal communication (eg lip reading) or has cochlear implant

question.questionText: 3. Rate function over the preceding 4 week period, according to patient and/or caregiver interview only. - Speech (mitochondrial_disease_adult_current_speech)

validValue.meaningText: 1. Communication unaffected but patient or others aware of changes in speech patterns or quality.
validValue.description: 1. Communication unaffected but patient or others aware of changes in speech patterns or quality.

validValue.meaningText: 2. Mild difficulties - usually understood and rarely asked to repeat things
validValue.description: 2. Mild difficulties - usually understood and rarely asked to repeat things

validValue.meaningText: 3. Moderate difficulties - poorly understood by strangers and frequently asked to repeat things.
validValue.description: 3. Moderate difficulties - poorly understood by strangers and frequently asked to repeat things.

validValue.meaningText: 4. Severe difficulties - poorly understood by family or friends.
validValue.description: 4. Severe difficulties - poorly understood by family or friends.

validValue.meaningText: 5. Not understood by family or friends. Requires communication aid.
validValue.description: 5. Not understood by family or friends. Requires communication aid.

question.questionText: 4. Rate function over the preceding 4 week period, according to patient and/or caregiver interview only. - Swallowing (mitochondrial_disease_adult_current_swallowing)

validValue.meaningText: 2. Sensation of solids 'sticking' (most meals) or need to modify diet (eg avoidance of steak/salad).
validValue.description: 2. Sensation of solids 'sticking' (most meals) or need to modify diet (eg avoidance of steak/salad).

validValue.meaningText: 3. Difficulty swallowing solids - affecting meal size or duration. Coughing, choking or nasal regurgitation infrequent (1 to 4 times per month) but more than peers.
validValue.description: 3. Difficulty swallowing solids - affecting meal size or duration. Coughing, choking or nasal regurgitation infrequent (1 to 4 times per month) but more than peers.

validValue.meaningText: 4. Requires adapted diet - regular coughing, choking, or nasal regurgitation (more than once per week).
validValue.description: 4. Requires adapted diet - regular coughing, choking, or nasal regurgitation (more than once per week).

question.questionText: 5. Rate function over the preceding 4 week period, according to patient and/or caregiver interview only. - Handwriting (mitochondrial_disease_adult_currenthandwriting)

validValue.meaningText: 1. Writing speed unaffected but aware of increasing untidiness.
validValue.description: 1. Writing speed unaffected but aware of increasing untidiness.

validValue.meaningText: 2. Mild - Has to write slower to maintain tidiness/legibility.
validValue.description: 2. Mild - Has to write slower to maintain tidiness/legibility.

validValue.meaningText: 3. Moderate - Handwriting takes at least twice as long or resorts to printing (must previously have used joined writing).
validValue.description: 3. Moderate - Handwriting takes at least twice as long or resorts to printing (must previously have used joined writing).

validValue.meaningText: 4. Severe - Handwriting mostly illegible. Printing very slow and untidy (eg 'THE BLACK CAT' takes in excess of 30 seconds).
validValue.description: 4. Severe - Handwriting mostly illegible. Printing very slow and untidy (eg 'THE BLACK CAT' takes in excess of 30 seconds).

validValue.meaningText: 5. Unable to write. No legible words.
validValue.description: 5. Unable to write. No legible words.

question.questionText: 6. Rate function over the preceding 4 week period, according to patient and/or caregiver interview only. - Cutting food and handling utensils (irrespective of contributory factors - eg weakness, coordination, cognitive function etc. This is also true for questions 7-10) (mitochondrial_disease_adult_current_cuttingfood)

validValue.meaningText: 1. Slightly slow and/or clumsy but minimal effect on meal duration.
validValue.description: 1. Slightly slow and/or clumsy but minimal effect on meal duration.

validValue.meaningText: 2. Slow and/or clumsy with extended meal duration, but no help required
validValue.description: 2. Slow and/or clumsy with extended meal duration, but no help required

validValue.meaningText: 3. Difficulty cutting up food and inaccuracy of transfer pronounced. Can manage alone but avoids problem foods (eg peas) or carer typically offers minor assistance (eg cutting up steak).
validValue.description: 3. Difficulty cutting up food and inaccuracy of transfer pronounced. Can manage alone but avoids problem foods (eg peas) or carer typically offers minor assistance (eg cutting up steak).

validValue.meaningText: 4. Unable to cut up food. Can pass food to mouth with great effort or inaccuracy. Resultant intake minimal. Requires major assistance.
validValue.description: 4. Unable to cut up food. Can pass food to mouth with great effort or inaccuracy. Resultant intake minimal. Requires major assistance.

question.questionText: 7. Rate function over the preceding 4 week period, according to patient and/or caregiver interview only. - Dressing (mitochondrial_disease_adult_current_dressing)

validValue.meaningText: 1. Occasional difficulties (eg shoe laces, buttons etc) but no real impact on time or effort taken to dress.
validValue.description: 1. Occasional difficulties (eg shoe laces, buttons etc) but no real impact on time or effort taken to dress.

validValue.meaningText: 2. Mild - Dressing takes longer and requires more effort than expected at the patient's age. No help required.
validValue.description: 2. Mild - Dressing takes longer and requires more effort than expected at the patient's age. No help required.

validValue.meaningText: 3. Moderate - Can dress unaided but takes at least twice as long and is a major effort. Carer typically helps with difficult tasks such as shoe laces or buttons.
validValue.description: 3. Moderate - Can dress unaided but takes at least twice as long and is a major effort. Carer typically helps with difficult tasks such as shoe laces or buttons.

validValue.meaningText: 4. Severe - Unable to dress without help but some tasks completed unaided.
validValue.description: 4. Severe - Unable to dress without help but some tasks completed unaided.

question.questionText: 8. Rate function over the preceding 4 week period, according to patient and/or caregiver interview only. - Hygiene (mitochondrial_disease_adult_current_hygiene)

validValue.meaningText: 1. Occasional difficulties only but no real impact on time or effort required.
validValue.description: 1. Occasional difficulties only but no real impact on time or effort required.

validValue.meaningText: 2. Mild - hygienic care takes longer but quality unaffected.
validValue.description: 2. Mild - hygienic care takes longer but quality unaffected.

validValue.meaningText: 3. Moderate - bathes and showers alone with difficulty or needs bath chair / modifications. Dextrous tasks (eg brushing teeth, combing hair) performed poorly.
validValue.description: 3. Moderate - bathes and showers alone with difficulty or needs bath chair / modifications. Dextrous tasks (eg brushing teeth, combing hair) performed poorly.

validValue.meaningText: 4. Severe - unable to bathe or shower without help. Major difficulty using toilet alone. Dextrous tasks require help.
validValue.description: 4. Severe - unable to bathe or shower without help. Major difficulty using toilet alone. Dextrous tasks require help.

validValue.meaningText: 5. Dependent upon carers to wash, bathe, and toilet.
validValue.description: 5. Dependent upon carers to wash, bathe, and toilet.

question.questionText: 9. Rate function over the preceding 4 week period, according to patient and/or caregiver interview only. - Exercise Tolerance (mitochondrial_disease_adult_current_exercisetolerance)

validValue.meaningText: 1. Unlimited on flat - symptomatic on inclines or stairs.
validValue.description: 1. Unlimited on flat - symptomatic on inclines or stairs.

validValue.meaningText: 2. Able to walk < 1000m on the flat. Restricted on inclines or stairs - rest needed after 1 flight (12 steps).
validValue.description: 2. Able to walk < 1000m on the flat. Restricted on inclines or stairs - rest needed after 1 flight (12 steps).

validValue.meaningText: 3. Able to walk < 500m on the flat. Rest needed after 8 steps on stairs.
validValue.description: 3. Able to walk < 500m on the flat. Rest needed after 8 steps on stairs.

validValue.meaningText: 4. Able to walk < 100m on the flat. Rest needed after 4 steps on stairs.
validValue.description: 4. Able to walk < 100m on the flat. Rest needed after 4 steps on stairs.

validValue.meaningText: 5. Able to walk < 25m on the flat. Unable to do stairs alone.
validValue.description: 5. Able to walk < 25m on the flat. Unable to do stairs alone.

question.questionText: 10. Rate function over the preceding 4 week period, according to patient and/or caregiver interview only. - Gait Stability (mitochondrial_disease_adult_current_gaitstability)

validValue.meaningText: 1. Normal gait - occasional difficulties on turns, uneven ground, or if required to balance on narrow base.
validValue.description: 1. Normal gait - occasional difficulties on turns, uneven ground, or if required to balance on narrow base.

validValue.meaningText: 2. Gait reasonably steady. Aware of impaired balance. Occasionally off balance when walking.
validValue.description: 2. Gait reasonably steady. Aware of impaired balance. Occasionally off balance when walking.

validValue.meaningText: 3. Unsteady gait. Always off balance when walking. Occasional falls. Gait steady with support of stick or person.
validValue.description: 3. Unsteady gait. Always off balance when walking. Occasional falls. Gait steady with support of stick or person.

validValue.meaningText: 4. Gait grossly unsteady without support. High likelihood of falls. Can only walk short distances (< 10m) without support.
validValue.description: 4. Gait grossly unsteady without support. High likelihood of falls. Can only walk short distances (< 10m) without support.

validValue.meaningText: 5. Unable to walk without support. Falls on standing.
validValue.description: 5. Unable to walk without support. Falls on standing.

question.questionText: Section II - System Specific Involvement. Rate function according to patient and/or caregiver interview and consultation with the medical notes. Each inquiry should take into account the situation for the preceding 12 month period only, unless otherwise stated in the question. (section_ii_220704)

System Specific Inviolvment - Each inquiry should take into account the situation for the preceding 12 month period only, unless otherwise stated in the question. - Psychiatric (mitochondrial_disease_adult_system_psychiatric)

validValue.meaningText: 1. Mild & transient (eg reactive depression) - lasting less than 3 months.
validValue.description: 1. Mild & transient (eg reactive depression) - lasting less than 3 months.

validValue.meaningText: 2. Mild & persistent (lasting more than 3 months) or recurrent. Patient has consulted GP.
validValue.description: 2. Mild & persistent (lasting more than 3 months) or recurrent. Patient has consulted GP.

validValue.meaningText: 3. Moderate & warranting specialist treatment (e.g. from a psychiatrist) - eg. bipolar disorder or depression with vegetative symptoms (insomnia, anorexia, abulia etc).
validValue.description: 3. Moderate & warranting specialist treatment (e.g. from a psychiatrist) - eg. bipolar disorder or depression with vegetative symptoms (insomnia, anorexia, abulia etc).

question.questionText: System Specific Inviolvment - Each inquiry should take into account the situation for the preceding 12 month period only, unless otherwise stated in the question. - Migraine Headaches During the last 3 months, how many days have headaches prevented the patient from functioning normally at school, work, or in the home? (mitochondrial_disease_adult_system_migraine)

validValue.meaningText: 1. Asymptomatic but past history of migraines.
validValue.description: 1. Asymptomatic but past history of migraines.

validValue.meaningText: 5. Four days per month or more.
validValue.description: 5. Four days per month or more.

question.questionText: System Specific Inviolvment - Each inquiry should take into account the situation for the preceding 12 month period only, unless otherwise stated in the question. - Seizures (mitochondrial_disease_adult_system_seizures)

validValue.meaningText: 1. Asymptomatic but past history of epilepsy.
validValue.description: 1. Asymptomatic but past history of epilepsy.

validValue.meaningText: 2. Myoclonic or simple partial seizures only.
validValue.description: 2. Myoclonic or simple partial seizures only.

validValue.meaningText: 3. Multiple absence, complex partial, or myoclonic seizures affecting function or single generalized seizure.
validValue.description: 3. Multiple absence, complex partial, or myoclonic seizures affecting function or single generalized seizure.

question.questionText: System Specific Inviolvment - Each inquiry should take into account the situation for the preceding 12 month period only, unless otherwise stated in the question. - Stroke-like episodes (exclude focal deficits felt to be of vascular aetiology) (mitochondrial_disease_adult_system_strokeepisodes)

validValue.meaningText: 1. Transient focal sensory symptoms only (less than 24 hours).
validValue.description: 1. Transient focal sensory symptoms only (less than 24 hours).

validValue.meaningText: 2. Transient focal motor symptoms only (less than 24 hours).
validValue.description: 2. Transient focal motor symptoms only (less than 24 hours).

validValue.meaningText: 3. Single stroke-like episode affecting one hemisphere (more than 24 hours).
validValue.description: 3. Single stroke-like episode affecting one hemisphere (more than 24 hours).

validValue.meaningText: 4. Single stroke-like episode affecting both hemispheres (more than 24 hours).
validValue.description: 4. Single stroke-like episode affecting both hemispheres (more than 24 hours).

validValue.meaningText: 5. Multiple stroke-like episodes (more than 24 hours each).
validValue.description: 5. Multiple stroke-like episodes (more than 24 hours each).

question.questionText: System Specific Inviolvment - Each inquiry should take into account the situation for the preceding 12 month period only, unless otherwise stated in the question. - Encephalopathic Episodes (mitochondrial_disease_adult_system_encephalopathic)

validValue.meaningText: 1. Asymptomatic but past history of encephalopathy.
validValue.description: 1. Asymptomatic but past history of encephalopathy.

validValue.meaningText: 2. Mild - single episode of personality or behavioural change but retaining orientation in time/place/person.
validValue.description: 2. Mild - single episode of personality or behavioural change but retaining orientation in time/place/person.

validValue.meaningText: 3. Moderate - single episode of confusion or disorientation in time, place or person.
validValue.description: 3. Moderate - single episode of confusion or disorientation in time, place or person.

validValue.meaningText: 4. Severe - multiple moderate episodes (as above) or emergency hospital admission due to encephalopathy without associated seizures or stroke-like episodes.
validValue.description: 4. Severe - multiple moderate episodes (as above) or emergency hospital admission due to encephalopathy without associated seizures or stroke-like episodes.

validValue.meaningText: 5. Very severe - in association with seizures, strokes or gross lactic acidaemia.
validValue.description: 5. Very severe - in association with seizures, strokes or gross lactic acidaemia.

question.questionText: System Specific Inviolvment - Each inquiry should take into account the situation for the preceding 12 month period only, unless otherwise stated in the question. - Gastro-intestinal symptoms (mitochondrial_disease_adult_system_gastro)

validValue.meaningText: 1. Mild constipation only or past history of bowel resection for dysmotility.
validValue.description: 1. Mild constipation only or past history of bowel resection for dysmotility.

validValue.meaningText: 2. Occasional symptoms of 'irritable bowel' (pain, bloating or diarrhoea) with long spells of normality.
validValue.description: 2. Occasional symptoms of 'irritable bowel' (pain, bloating or diarrhoea) with long spells of normality.

validValue.meaningText: 3. Frequent symptoms (as above) most weeks or severe constipation with bowels open less than once/week or need for daily medications.
validValue.description: 3. Frequent symptoms (as above) most weeks or severe constipation with bowels open less than once/week or need for daily medications.

validValue.meaningText: 4. Dysmotility requiring admission or persistent and/or recurrent anorexia/vomiting/weight loss.
validValue.description: 4. Dysmotility requiring admission or persistent and/or recurrent anorexia/vomiting/weight loss.

validValue.meaningText: 5. Surgical procedures or resections for gastrointestinal dysmotility.
validValue.description: 5. Surgical procedures or resections for gastrointestinal dysmotility.

question.questionText: System Specific Inviolvment - Each inquiry should take into account the situation for the preceding 12 month period only, unless otherwise stated in the question. - Diabetes mellitus (mitochondrial_disease_adult_system_diabetes)

validValue.meaningText: 1. Past history of gestational diabetes or transient glucose intolerance related to intercurrent illness.
validValue.description: 1. Past history of gestational diabetes or transient glucose intolerance related to intercurrent illness.

validValue.meaningText: 2. Impaired glucose tolerance (in absence of intercurrent illness).
validValue.description: 2. Impaired glucose tolerance (in absence of intercurrent illness).

validValue.meaningText: 5. DM requiring insulin (irrespective of treatment at onset).
validValue.description: 5. DM requiring insulin (irrespective of treatment at onset).

question.questionText: System Specific Inviolvment - Each inquiry should take into account the situation for the preceding 12 month period only, unless otherwise stated in the question. - Respiratory muscle weakness (mitochondrial_disease_adult_system_respiratorymuscle_weakness)

validValue.meaningText: 5. FVC < 45% predicted or ventilator support for over 6 hours per 24 hr period (not for OSA alone).
validValue.description: 5. FVC < 45% predicted or ventilator support for over 6 hours per 24 hr period (not for OSA alone).

question.questionText: System Specific Inviolvment - Each inquiry should take into account the situation for the preceding 12 month period only, unless otherwise stated in the question. - Cardiovascular system (mitochondrial_disease_adult_system_cardiovascular)

validValue.meaningText: 2. Asymptomatic LVH on echo or non-sustained brady/tachyarrhythmia on ECG.
validValue.description: 2. Asymptomatic LVH on echo or non-sustained brady/tachyarrhythmia on ECG.

validValue.meaningText: 3. Sustained or symptomatic arrhythmia, LVH or cardiomyopathy. Dilated chambers or reduced function on echo. Mobitz II AV block or greater.
validValue.description: 3. Sustained or symptomatic arrhythmia, LVH or cardiomyopathy. Dilated chambers or reduced function on echo. Mobitz II AV block or greater.

validValue.meaningText: 4. Requires pacemaker, defibrillator, arrhythmia ablation, or LVEF < 35% on echocardiogram.
validValue.description: 4. Requires pacemaker, defibrillator, arrhythmia ablation, or LVEF < 35% on echocardiogram.

validValue.meaningText: 5. Symptoms of left ventricular failure with clinical and/or x-ray evidence of pulmonary oedema or LVEF < 30% on echocardiogram.
validValue.description: 5. Symptoms of left ventricular failure with clinical and/or x-ray evidence of pulmonary oedema or LVEF < 30% on echocardiogram.

question.questionText: Section III - Current Clinical Assessment. Rate current status according to examination performed at the time of assessment (section_iii_220704)

validValue.meaningText: 1. Some restriction of eye movement (any direction). Abduction complete.
validValue.description: 1. Some restriction of eye movement (any direction). Abduction complete.

validValue.description: 3. Abduction of worst eye below 60% of normal.

validValue.meaningText: 2. Mild - clear impairment but easily understood.
validValue.description: 2. Mild - clear impairment but easily understood.

validValue.meaningText: 3. Moderate - some words poorly understood and infrequent repetition needed.
validValue.description: 3. Moderate - some words poorly understood and infrequent repetition needed.

question.questionText: Rate current status according to examination performed at the time of assessment. Myopathy (mitochondrial_disease_adult_currentclinical_myopathy)

validValue.meaningText: 1. Minimal reduction in hip flexion and/or shoulder abduction only (eg MRC 4+/5).
validValue.description: 1. Minimal reduction in hip flexion and/or shoulder abduction only (eg MRC 4+/5).

validValue.meaningText: 2. Mild but clear proximal weakness in hip flexion and shoulder abduction (MRC 4/5). Minimal weakness in elbow flexion and knee extension (MRC 4+/5 - both examined with joint at 90 degrees).
validValue.description: 2. Mild but clear proximal weakness in hip flexion and shoulder abduction (MRC 4/5). Minimal weakness in elbow flexion and knee extension (MRC 4+/5 - both examined with joint at 90 degrees).

validValue.meaningText: 3. Moderate proximal weakness including elbow flexion & knee extension (MRC 4/5 or 4 -/5) or difficulty rising from a 90 degree squat.
validValue.description: 3. Moderate proximal weakness including elbow flexion & knee extension (MRC 4/5 or 4 -/5) or difficulty rising from a 90 degree squat.

validValue.meaningText: 4. Waddling gait. Unable to rise from a 90 degree squat ,a chair unaided.
validValue.description: 4. Waddling gait. Unable to rise from a 90 degree squat ,a chair unaided.

validValue.meaningText: 5. Wheelchair dependent primarily due to proximal weakness.
validValue.description: 5. Wheelchair dependent primarily due to proximal weakness.

question.questionText: Rate current status according to examination performed at the time of assessment. Cerebellar ataxia (mitochondrial_disease_adult_currentclinical_cerebellarataxia)

validValue.meaningText: 2. Gait reasonably steady. Unable to maintain heel-toe walking or mild UL dysmetria.
validValue.description: 2. Gait reasonably steady. Unable to maintain heel-toe walking or mild UL dysmetria.

validValue.meaningText: 3. Ataxic gait (but walks unaided) or UL intention tremor & past-pointing. Unable to walk heel-toe - falls immediately.
validValue.description: 3. Ataxic gait (but walks unaided) or UL intention tremor & past-pointing. Unable to walk heel-toe - falls immediately.

validValue.description: 4. Severe - gait grossly unsteady without support or UL ataxia sufficient to affect feeding.

validValue.description: 4. Sensory ataxia or motor effects severely limit ambulation.

validValue.description: 3. Moderate hemiplegia allowing unaided ambulation or dense UL monoplegia.

validValue.description: 1. Mild and unilateral. Not disabling (H&Y stage 1).

validValue.meaningText: 2. Mild and bilateral. Minimal disability. Gait affected (H&Y stage 2).
validValue.description: 2. Mild and bilateral. Minimal disability. Gait affected (H&Y stage 2).

validValue.description: 3. Moderate. Significant slowing of body movements (H&Y stage 3)

validValue.meaningText: 4. Severe. Rigidity and bradykinesia. Unable to live alone. Can walk to limited extent (H&Y stage 4).
validValue.description: 4. Severe. Rigidity and bradykinesia. Unable to live alone. Can walk to limited extent (H&Y stage 4).

question.questionText: Rate current status according to examination performed at the time of assessment. Cognition (mitochondrial_disease_adult_currentclinical_cognition)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Newcastle Paediatric Mitochondrial Disease Scale (NPMDS) and the Newcastle Mitochondrial Disease Adult Scale (NMDAS) can be used to evaluate the progression of mitochondrial disease. There are three versions of the NPMDS, each for a specific age range (0-24 months, 2-11 years, and 12-18 years). The NMDAS is for adult patients over 16 years. The investigators from Newcastle University recommend that if the child experiences early onset of a mitochondrial disease in childhood, the NPMDS 12-18 year scale should be used. If an adolescent experiences onset of a mitochondrial disease, the investigators recommend switching to the NMDAS scale at 16 years. The aim of the scales is to allow for standardization of patient assessment and to improve accurate data collection. The scales are composed of multiple domains: Current Function, System Specific Involvement, Current Clinical Assessment, and Quality of Life. Almost all questions provide a score which ranges from 0-3, with the following representations: 0 is normal, 1 is mild, 2 is moderate, and 3 is severe. Examples of the severity for each question are provided. Depending on the domain, the questions are either self- or interviewer-administrated, based on a providers clinical assessment or medical records. There is a manual for each scale, which details the administration, process, and scoring instructions.

form.longName: PhenX PX240801 - Family History Of Pregnancy Complications
form.preferredDefinition: A two-item, multi-part set of interviewer-administered questions about the woman's family members who have had pregnancy complications. The relationship between the woman and her family members and the list of pregnancy complications are coded.

question.questionText: Have any of your biological mother, sisters, half-sisters, or female first cousins ever had the following pregnancy complication? Delivery of a child more than 3 weeks before the expected due date (pregnancy_history_more_three_weeks_premature)

Have any of your biological mother, sisters, half-sisters, or female first cousins ever had the following pregnancy complication? Delivery of a child weighing less than 5 lb 8 oz (or 2500 grams) (pregnancy_history_weight_premature)

Have any of your biological mother, sisters, half-sisters, or female first cousins ever had the following pregnancy complication? Spontaneous preterm delivery (< 37 weeks) (pregnancy_history_spontaneous_preterm_delivery)

Have any of your biological mother, sisters, half-sisters, or female first cousins ever had the following pregnancy complication? Early or preterm rupture of the membranes (pregnancy_history_preterm_membrane_rupture)

Have any of your biological mother, sisters, half-sisters, or female first cousins ever had the following pregnancy complication? Preeclampsia, eclampsia, toxemia, or pregnancy-induced hypertension (pregnancy_history_preeclampsia)

Have any of your biological mother, sisters, half-sisters, or female first cousins ever had the following pregnancy complication? Induction of labor due to low amniotic fluid or poor fetal growth (pregnancy_history_low_amniotic_fluid)
Have any of your biological mother, sisters, half-sisters, or female first cousins ever had the following pregnancy complication? Stillbirth (pregnancy_history_stillbirth)

Have any of your biological mother, sisters, half-sisters, or female first cousins ever had the following pregnancy complication? Delivery of an infant with a birth defect (pregnancy_history_birth_defect)

Have any of your biological mother, sisters, half-sisters, or female first cousins ever had the following pregnancy complication? Other pregnancy complication, specify (pregnancy_history_other_complications)

protocol.preferredDefinition: A two-item, multi-part set of interviewer-administered questions about the woman's family members who have had pregnancy complications. The relationship between the woman and her family members and the list of pregnancy complications are coded.

form.longName: PhenX PX250401 - Knee Injury And Osteoarthritis
form.preferredDefinition: Determination of fetal growth is a three-step process: Step 1: Ascertainment of estimated fetal weight (EFW) Step 2: Verification of gestational age (GA) at which the EFW was recorded Step 3: Determination of EFW or biometry percentiles by plotting the EFW or relevant biometric measures at the appropriate GA on a pre-defined fetal growth curve

question.questionText: Do you have swelling in your knee? (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Swelling)
Do you feel grinding, hear clicking or any other type of noise when your knee moves? (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Grinding_Clicking_Noise)
Does your knee catch or hang up when moving? (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Catch_Hang_Moving)
Can you straighten your knee fully? (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Straighten_Fully)
Can you bend your knee fully? (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Bend_Fully)
How severe is your knee joint stiffness after first wakening in the morning? (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Stiffness_Morning)
How severe is your knee stiffness after sitting, lying or resting later in the day? (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Stiffness_Sitting_Lying_Resting)
How often do you experience knee pain? (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Pain_Frequency)
What amount of knee pain have you experienced the last week during the following activities? Twisting/pivoting on your knee (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Pain_Twisting_Pivoting)
What amount of knee pain have you experienced the last week during the following activities? Straightening knee fully (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Pain_Straighten_Fully)
What amount of knee pain have you experienced the last week during the following activities? Bending knee fully (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Pain_Bend_Fully)
What amount of knee pain have you experienced the last week during the following activities? Walking on flat surface (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Pain_Walking_Flat_Surface)
What amount of knee pain have you experienced the last week during the following activities? Going up or down stairs (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Pain_Stairs)
What amount of knee pain have you experienced the last week during the following activities? At night while in bed (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Pain_Night_Bed)
What amount of knee pain have you experienced the last week during the following activities? Sitting or lying (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Pain_Sitting_Lying)
What amount of knee pain have you experienced the last week during the following activities? Standing upright (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Pain_Standing_Upright)

For each of the following activities please indicate the degree of difficulty you have experienced in the last week due to your knee. Descending stairs (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Function_Descend_Stairs)

For each of the following activities please indicate the degree of difficulty you have experienced in the last week due to your knee. Ascending stairs (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Function_Ascend_Stairs)

For each of the following activities please indicate the degree of difficulty you have experienced in the last week due to your knee. Rising from sitting (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Function_Rising_Sitting)
For each of the following activities please indicate the degree of difficulty you have experienced in the last week due to your knee. Standing (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Function_Standing)

For each of the following activities please indicate the degree of difficulty you have experienced in the last week due to your knee. Bending to floor/pick up an object (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Function_Bending_Floor)

For each of the following activities please indicate the degree of difficulty you have experienced in the last week due to your knee. Walking on flat surface (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Function_Walking_Flat_Surface)

For each of the following activities please indicate the degree of difficulty you have experienced in the last week due to your knee. Getting in/out of car (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Function_Enter_Exit_Car)
For each of the following activities please indicate the degree of difficulty you have experienced in the last week due to your knee. Going shopping (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Function_Shopping)

For each of the following activities please indicate the degree of difficulty you have experienced in the last week due to your knee. Putting on socks/stockings (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Function_Socks_Stockings)
For each of the following activities please indicate the degree of difficulty you have experienced in the last week due to your knee. Rising from bed (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Function_Rising_Bed)

For each of the following activities please indicate the degree of difficulty you have experienced in the last week due to your knee. Taking off socks/stockings (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Function_Remove_Stocks_Stockings)

For each of the following activities please indicate the degree of difficulty you have experienced in the last week due to your knee. Lying in bed (turning over, maintaining knee position) (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Function_Lying)

For each of the following activities please indicate the degree of difficulty you have experienced in the last week due to your knee. Getting in/out of bath (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Function_Bathtub)
For each of the following activities please indicate the degree of difficulty you have experienced in the last week due to your knee. Sitting (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Function_Sitting)

For each of the following activities please indicate the degree of difficulty you have experienced in the last week due to your knee. Getting on/off toilet (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Function_Toilet)

For each of the following activities please indicate the degree of difficulty you have experienced in the last week due to your knee. Heavy domestic duties (moving heavy boxes, scrubbing floors, etc.) (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Function_Heavy_Domestic_Duties)

For each of the following activities please indicate the degree of difficulty you have experienced in the last week due to your knee. Light domestic duties (cooking, dusting, etc.) (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Function_Light_Domestic_Duties)
The questions should be answered thinking of what degree of difficulty you have experienced during the last week due to your knee. Squatting (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Function_Squatting)
The questions should be answered thinking of what degree of difficulty you have experienced during the last week due to your knee. Running (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Function_Running)
The questions should be answered thinking of what degree of difficulty you have experienced during the last week due to your knee. Jumping (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Function_Jumping)

The questions should be answered thinking of what degree of difficulty you have experienced during the last week due to your knee. Twisting/pivoting on your injured knee (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Function_Twisting_Pivoting)
The questions should be answered thinking of what degree of difficulty you have experienced during the last week due to your knee. Kneeling (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Function_Kneeling)
How often are you aware of your knee problem? (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Quality_Life_Awareness)
Have you modified your life style to avoid potentially damaging activities to your knee? (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Quality_Life_Change)
How much are you troubled with lack of confidence in your knee? (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Quality_Life_Confidence)
In general, how much difficulty do you have with your knee? (Knee_Injury_Osteoarthritis_Quality_Life_Difficulty)

question.questionText: Compared with two years ago, how is R's FIRST NAME at: Remembering things about family and friends, such as occupations, birthdays, and addresses. Has this improved, not much changed, or gotten worse? Compared with [when we interviewed [him/her] in R's LAST IW MONTH, YEAR/two years ago], how was R's FIRST NAME at: Remembering things about family and friends, such as occupations, birthdays, and addresses. Had this improved, not much changed, or gotten worse? (Cognitive_Changes_Family_Memory_Status)

validValue.meaningText: DOES NOT APPLY; R DOESN'T DO ACTIVITY

protocol.preferredDefinition: Determination of fetal growth is a three-step process: Step 1: Ascertainment of estimated fetal weight (EFW) Step 2: Verification of gestational age (GA) at which the EFW was recorded Step 3: Determination of EFW or biometry percentiles by plotting the EFW or relevant biometric measures at the appropriate GA on a pre-defined fetal growth curve

form.longName: PhenX PX540603 - Sensitivity To Punishment Sensitivity To Reward Question
form.preferredDefinition: The Sensitivity to Punishment/Sensitivity to Reward Questionnaire (SPSRQ) is a self-reported instrument that includes 48 yes/no questions divided into two subscales: Sensitivity to Reward (SR) and Sensitivity to Punishment (SP).

module.longName: Sensitivity To Punishment Sensitivity To Reward Question
module.preferredDefinition: Sensitivity To Punishment Sensitivity To Reward Question

question.questionText: Do you often refrain from doing something because you are afraid of it being illegal? (SPSRQ_NotDoSomething_Fear_Legality)
Does the good prospect of obtaining money motivate you strongly to do some things? (SPSRQ_ProspectOf_Money_Motivation)
Do you prefer not to ask for something when you are not sure you will obtain it? (SPSRQ_NotToAskWhen_NotSure_Obtainable)
Are you frequently encouraged to act by the possibility of being valued in your work, in your studies, with your friends or with your family? (SPSRQ_Encouraged_ToAct_ToBe_Valued)
Are you often afraid of new or unexpected situations? (SPSRQ_Often_Afraid_NewUnexpected_Situations)
Do you often meet people that you find physically attractive? (SPSRQ_Meet_People_Physically_Attractive)
Is it difficult for you to telephone someone you do not know? (SPSRQ_Difficulty_Telephone_Stranger)
Do you like to take some drugs because of the pleasure you get from them? (SPSRQ_Get_Pleasure_From_Drugs)
Do you often renounce your rights when you know you can avoid a quarrel with a person or an organization? (SPSRQ_Renounce_Rights_Avoid_Quarrel)
Do you often do things to be praised? (SPSRQ_Often_Do_Things_ForPraise)
As a child, were you troubled by punishments at home or in school? (SPSRQ_TroubledBy_Punishments_At_HomeSchool)
Do you like being the center of attention at a party or a social meeting? (SPSRQ_CenterOf_Attention_PartySocialMeeting)
In tasks that you are not prepared for, do you attach great importance to the possibility of failure? (SPSRQ_ImportanceOn_PossibilityOf_Failure)
Do you spend a lot of your time on obtaining a good image? (SPSRQ_Time_Spent_Obtaining_Image)
Are you easily discouraged in difficult situations? (SPSRQ_DiscouragedIn_Difficult_Situations)
Do you need people to show their affection for you all the time? (SPSRQ_Need_Constant_ShowOf_Affection)
Are you a shy person? (SPSRQ_Shy_Person)
When you are in a group, do you try to make your opinions the most intelligent or the funniest? (SPSRQ_InGroup_Make_MostIntelligentFunniest_Comments)
Whenever possible, do you avoid demonstrating your skills for fear of being embarrassed? (SPSRQ_Avoid_Demonstrating_Fear_Embarrassment)
Do you often take the opportunity to pick up people you find attractive? (SPSRQ_Often_PickUp_Attractive_People)
When you are with a group, do you have difficulties selecting a good topic to talk about? (SPSRQ_Group_Difficulty_Discussion_Topic)
As a child, did you do a lot of things to get peoples approval? (SPSRQ_Do_ThingsFor_Approval_AsChild)
Is it often difficult for you to fall asleep when you think about things you have done or must do? (SPSRQ_Difficulty_Sleep_ThingsToDo)
Does the possibility of social advancement, move you to action, even if this involves not playing fair? (SPSRQ_SocialAdvancement_Motivation_NotFairPlay)
Do you think a lot before complaining in a restaurant if your meal is not well prepared? (SPSRQ_ThinkBefore_Complaining_Restaurant_Meal)
Do you generally give preferences to those activities that imply an immediate gain? (SPSRQ_GivePreferenceTo_Activities_With_ImmediateGain)
Would you be bothered if you had to return to a store when you noticed you were given the wrong change? (SPSRQ_BotheredTo_Return_Store_WrongChange)
Do you often have trouble resisting the temptation of doing forbidden things? (SPSRQ_Difficulty_Resisting_Temptation_ForbiddenThings)
Whenever you can, do you avoid going to unknown places? (SPSRQ_Avoid_Going_Unknown_Places)
Do you like to compete and do everything you can to win? (SPSRQ_Compete_DoEverything)
Are you often worried by things that you said or did? (SPSRQ_WorriedBy_Things_You_SaidDid)
Is it easy for you to associate tastes and smells to very pleasant events? (SPSRQ_Associate_TastesSmells_Pleasant_Events)
Would it be difficult for you to ask your boss for a raise (salary increase)? (SPSRQ_Difficult_Ask_Boss_SalaryIncrease)
Are there a large number of objects or sensations that remind you of pleasant events? (SPSRQ_Objects_Sensations_Reminder_PleasantEvents)
Do you generally try to avoid speaking in public? (SPSRQ_Avoid_Public_Speaking)
When you start to play with a slot machine, is it often difficult for you to stop? (SPSRQ_Difficult_ToStop_SlotMachine)
Do you, on a regular basis, think that you could do more things if it was not for your insecurity or fear? (SPSRQ_CouldDoMore_Without_InsecurityFear)
Do you sometimes do things for quick gains? (SPSRQ_Do_ThingsFor_QuickGains)
Comparing yourself to people you know, are you afraid of many things? (SPSRQ_FearOf_Many_Things)
Does your attention easily stray from your work in the presence of an attractive stranger? (SPSRQ_DistractedFrom_Work_Attractive_Stranger)
Do you often find yourself worrying about things to the extent that performance in intellectual abilities is impaired? (SPSRQ_Worry_Impairs_intellectual_Performance)
Are you interested in money to the point of being able to do risky jobs? (SPSRQ_Money_Motivate_Risky_Jobs)
Do you often refrain from doing something you like in order not to be rejected or disapproved of by others? (SPSRQ_Refrain_DoingSomething_Avoid_DisapprovalRejection)
Do you like to put competitive ingredients in all of your activities? (SPSRQ_Competitive_Ingredients_All_Activities)
Generally, do you pay more attention to threats than to pleasant events? (SPSRQ_More_Attention_To_Threats)
Would you like to be a socially powerful person? (SPSRQ_Socially_Powerful_Person)
Do you often refrain from doing something because of your fear of being embarrassed? (SPSRQ_Refrain_DoingSomething_Fear_Embarrassment)
Do you like displaying your physical abilities even though this may involve danger? (SPSRQ_Display_PhysicalAbilities_Involve_Danger)

protocol.longName: Sensitivity to Punishment/Sensitivity to Reward Questionnaire (SPSRQ)
protocol.preferredDefinition: The Sensitivity to Punishment/Sensitivity to Reward Questionnaire (SPSRQ) is a self-reported instrument that includes 48 yes/no questions divided into two subscales: Sensitivity to Reward (SR) and Sensitivity to Punishment (SP).

form.longName: PhenX PX661201 - Social And Role Dysfunction In Psychosis And Schizophren
form.preferredDefinition: Global Functioning: Social and Global Functioning: Role scales are 7 social-scale prompts and 4-item clinician-administered interviews that include detailed anchors for prodromal problems relevant for the typical age range for the prodromal phase. Each question is scored on a 10-point scale (10 = superior function; 1 = extreme dysfunction) and captures current functioning, lowest functioning over the past year, and highest functioning over the past year. Example prompts/questions are included.

module.longName: Social And Role Dysfunction In Psychosis And Schizophren
module.preferredDefinition: Social And Role Dysfunction In Psychosis And Schizophren

question.questionText: [CURRENT RATING] Tell me about your social life. Do you have friends? (socialglobal_functioning_social_life_current)

validValue.meaningText: Extreme social isolation. No social or family member contact at all. Does not leave home. Refuses to answer the phone or door.
validValue.description: Extreme social isolation. No social or family member contact at all. Does not leave home. Refuses to answer the phone or door.

validValue.meaningText: Inability to function socially - Unable to function socially or to maintain any interpersonal relationships. Typically alone and socially isolated. Rarely leaves home. Rarely answers the phone or the door. Rarely participates in interactions with others at home or in other settings (e.g., work, school).
validValue.description: Inability to function socially - Unable to function socially or to maintain any interpersonal relationships. Typically alone and socially isolated. Rarely leaves home. Rarely answers the phone or the door. Rarely participates in interactions with others at home or in other settings (e.g., work, school).

validValue.meaningText: Marginal ability to function socially. Marginal ability to function socially or maintain interpersonal relationships. Frequently alone and socially isolated. Serious impairment in relationships with all peers, including acquaintances. Few interactions with family members (e.g., often alone in room). Serious impairment in communication with others (e.g., avoids participating in most social activities).
validValue.description: Marginal ability to function socially. Marginal ability to function socially or maintain interpersonal relationships. Frequently alone and socially isolated. Serious impairment in relationships with all peers, including acquaintances. Few interactions with family members (e.g., often alone in room). Serious impairment in communication with others (e.g., avoids participating in most social activities).

validValue.meaningText: Major impairment in social and interpersonal functioning - Major impairment in social functioning. Serious impairment in relationships with friends or peers (e.g., very few or no friends, frequent conflicts with friends, or frequently avoids friends). Frequent combative or verbally argumentative behavior with peers. Infrequent contact with family members (e.g., sometimes does not respond to family or avoids family members).
validValue.description: Major impairment in social and interpersonal functioning - Major impairment in social functioning. Serious impairment in relationships with friends or peers (e.g., very few or no friends, frequent conflicts with friends, or frequently avoids friends). Frequent combative or verbally argumentative behavior with peers. Infrequent contact with family members (e.g., sometimes does not respond to family or avoids family members).

validValue.meaningText: Serious impairment in social/interpersonal functioning - Serious impairment in social functioning. No close friends or intimate partner but has some casual social contacts (e.g., acquaintances, school/work friends only). Rarely seeks out others. Occasional combative or verbally argumentative behavior with peers. Beginning to withdraw from family members (e.g., does not initiate conversation with family, but will respond if addressed).
validValue.description: Serious impairment in social/interpersonal functioning - Serious impairment in social functioning. No close friends or intimate partner but has some casual social contacts (e.g., acquaintances, school/work friends only). Rarely seeks out others. Occasional combative or verbally argumentative behavior with peers. Beginning to withdraw from family members (e.g., does not initiate conversation with family, but will respond if addressed).

validValue.meaningText: Moderate impairment in social/interpersonal functioning - Moderate impairment in social functioning. Moderate impairment present (e.g., few close friends; significant but intermittent conflicts with peers, coworkers, or classmates). Moderate difficulty developing age-appropriate intimate relationships (e.g., infrequent dating). Occasionally seeks out others but will respond if invited by others to participate in an activity.
validValue.description: Moderate impairment in social/interpersonal functioning - Moderate impairment in social functioning. Moderate impairment present (e.g., few close friends; significant but intermittent conflicts with peers, coworkers, or classmates). Moderate difficulty developing age-appropriate intimate relationships (e.g., infrequent dating). Occasionally seeks out others but will respond if invited by others to participate in an activity.

validValue.meaningText: Mild problems in social/interpersonal functioning - Some persistent mild difficulty in social functioning. Mild impairment present that is NOT just expectable reaction to psychosocial stressors (e.g., mild conflicts with peers, coworkers or classmates; difficulty resolving conflicts appropriately). Has some meaningful interpersonal relationships with peers (casual and/or close friends). Some difficulty developing or maintaining age-appropriate intimate relationships (e.g., multiple short-term
validValue.description: Mild problems in social/interpersonal functioning - Some persistent mild difficulty in social functioning. Mild impairment present that is NOT just expectable reaction to psychosocial stressors (e.g., mild conflicts with peers, coworkers or classmates; difficulty resolving conflicts appropriately). Has some meaningful interpersonal relationships with peers (casual and/or close friends). Some difficulty developing or maintaining age-appropriate intimate relationships (e.g., multiple short-term

validValue.meaningText: Good social/interpersonal functioning - Some transient mild impairment in social functioning. Mild social impairment is present, but transient and expectable reactions to psychosocial stressors (e.g., after minor arguments with spouse, girlfriend/boyfriend, friends, coworkers, or classmates). Has some meaningful interpersonal relationships with peers (casual and close friends), and/or age-appropriate intimate relationships. Infrequent interpersonal conflict with peers.
validValue.description: Good social/interpersonal functioning - Some transient mild impairment in social functioning. Mild social impairment is present, but transient and expectable reactions to psychosocial stressors (e.g., after minor arguments with spouse, girlfriend/boyfriend, friends, coworkers, or classmates). Has some meaningful interpersonal relationships with peers (casual and close friends), and/or age-appropriate intimate relationships. Infrequent interpersonal conflict with peers.

validValue.meaningText: Above average social/interpersonal functioning - Good functioning in all social areas, and interpersonally effective. Interested and involved in a wide range of social and interpersonal activities, including both close and casual friends. Age-appropriate involvement in intimate relationships. No more than everyday interpersonal problems or concerns (e.g., an occasional argument with spouse, girlfriend/boyfriend, friends, coworkers, or classmates). Able to resolve such conflicts appropriately.
validValue.description: Above average social/interpersonal functioning - Good functioning in all social areas, and interpersonally effective. Interested and involved in a wide range of social and interpersonal activities, including both close and casual friends. Age-appropriate involvement in intimate relationships. No more than everyday interpersonal problems or concerns (e.g., an occasional argument with spouse, girlfriend/boyfriend, friends, coworkers, or classmates). Able to resolve such conflicts appropriately.

validValue.meaningText: Superior social/interpersonal functioning - Superior functioning in a wide range of social and interpersonal activities. Frequently seeks out others and has multiple satisfying interpersonal relationships, including multiple close and casual friends. Is sought out by others because of his or her many positive qualities. Age-appropriate involvement in intimate relationships.
validValue.description: Superior social/interpersonal functioning - Superior functioning in a wide range of social and interpersonal activities. Frequently seeks out others and has multiple satisfying interpersonal relationships, including multiple close and casual friends. Is sought out by others because of his or her many positive qualities. Age-appropriate involvement in intimate relationships.

question.questionText: [CURRENT RATING] Are they casual or close friends? If only casual-are they school or work friends only? If close-how long have you been close friends? (socialglobal_functioning_friends_current)

validValue.meaningText: Extreme social isolation. No social or family member contact at all. Does not leave home. Refuses to answer the phone or door.
validValue.description: Extreme social isolation. No social or family member contact at all. Does not leave home. Refuses to answer the phone or door.

validValue.meaningText: Inability to function socially - Unable to function socially or to maintain any interpersonal relationships. Typically alone and socially isolated. Rarely leaves home. Rarely answers the phone or the door. Rarely participates in interactions with others at home or in other settings (e.g., work, school).
validValue.description: Inability to function socially - Unable to function socially or to maintain any interpersonal relationships. Typically alone and socially isolated. Rarely leaves home. Rarely answers the phone or the door. Rarely participates in interactions with others at home or in other settings (e.g., work, school).

validValue.meaningText: Marginal ability to function socially. Marginal ability to function socially or maintain interpersonal relationships. Frequently alone and socially isolated. Serious impairment in relationships with all peers, including acquaintances. Few interactions with family members (e.g., often alone in room). Serious impairment in communication with others (e.g., avoids participating in most social activities).
validValue.description: Marginal ability to function socially. Marginal ability to function socially or maintain interpersonal relationships. Frequently alone and socially isolated. Serious impairment in relationships with all peers, including acquaintances. Few interactions with family members (e.g., often alone in room). Serious impairment in communication with others (e.g., avoids participating in most social activities).

validValue.meaningText: Major impairment in social and interpersonal functioning - Major impairment in social functioning. Serious impairment in relationships with friends or peers (e.g., very few or no friends, frequent conflicts with friends, or frequently avoids friends). Frequent combative or verbally argumentative behavior with peers. Infrequent contact with family members (e.g., sometimes does not respond to family or avoids family members).
validValue.description: Major impairment in social and interpersonal functioning - Major impairment in social functioning. Serious impairment in relationships with friends or peers (e.g., very few or no friends, frequent conflicts with friends, or frequently avoids friends). Frequent combative or verbally argumentative behavior with peers. Infrequent contact with family members (e.g., sometimes does not respond to family or avoids family members).

validValue.meaningText: Serious impairment in social/interpersonal functioning - Serious impairment in social functioning. No close friends or intimate partner but has some casual social contacts (e.g., acquaintances, school/work friends only). Rarely seeks out others. Occasional combative or verbally argumentative behavior with peers. Beginning to withdraw from family members (e.g., does not initiate conversation with family, but will respond if addressed).
validValue.description: Serious impairment in social/interpersonal functioning - Serious impairment in social functioning. No close friends or intimate partner but has some casual social contacts (e.g., acquaintances, school/work friends only). Rarely seeks out others. Occasional combative or verbally argumentative behavior with peers. Beginning to withdraw from family members (e.g., does not initiate conversation with family, but will respond if addressed).

validValue.meaningText: Moderate impairment in social/interpersonal functioning - Moderate impairment in social functioning. Moderate impairment present (e.g., few close friends; significant but intermittent conflicts with peers, coworkers, or classmates). Moderate difficulty developing age-appropriate intimate relationships (e.g., infrequent dating). Occasionally seeks out others but will respond if invited by others to participate in an activity.
validValue.description: Moderate impairment in social/interpersonal functioning - Moderate impairment in social functioning. Moderate impairment present (e.g., few close friends; significant but intermittent conflicts with peers, coworkers, or classmates). Moderate difficulty developing age-appropriate intimate relationships (e.g., infrequent dating). Occasionally seeks out others but will respond if invited by others to participate in an activity.

validValue.meaningText: Mild problems in social/interpersonal functioning - Some persistent mild difficulty in social functioning. Mild impairment present that is NOT just expectable reaction to psychosocial stressors (e.g., mild conflicts with peers, coworkers or classmates; difficulty resolving conflicts appropriately). Has some meaningful interpersonal relationships with peers (casual and/or close friends). Some difficulty developing or maintaining age-appropriate intimate relationships (e.g., multiple short-term
validValue.description: Mild problems in social/interpersonal functioning - Some persistent mild difficulty in social functioning. Mild impairment present that is NOT just expectable reaction to psychosocial stressors (e.g., mild conflicts with peers, coworkers or classmates; difficulty resolving conflicts appropriately). Has some meaningful interpersonal relationships with peers (casual and/or close friends). Some difficulty developing or maintaining age-appropriate intimate relationships (e.g., multiple short-term

validValue.meaningText: Good social/interpersonal functioning - Some transient mild impairment in social functioning. Mild social impairment is present, but transient and expectable reactions to psychosocial stressors (e.g., after minor arguments with spouse, girlfriend/boyfriend, friends, coworkers, or classmates). Has some meaningful interpersonal relationships with peers (casual and close friends), and/or age-appropriate intimate relationships. Infrequent interpersonal conflict with peers.
validValue.description: Good social/interpersonal functioning - Some transient mild impairment in social functioning. Mild social impairment is present, but transient and expectable reactions to psychosocial stressors (e.g., after minor arguments with spouse, girlfriend/boyfriend, friends, coworkers, or classmates). Has some meaningful interpersonal relationships with peers (casual and close friends), and/or age-appropriate intimate relationships. Infrequent interpersonal conflict with peers.

validValue.meaningText: Above average social/interpersonal functioning - Good functioning in all social areas, and interpersonally effective. Interested and involved in a wide range of social and interpersonal activities, including both close and casual friends. Age-appropriate involvement in intimate relationships. No more than everyday interpersonal problems or concerns (e.g., an occasional argument with spouse, girlfriend/boyfriend, friends, coworkers, or classmates). Able to resolve such conflicts appropriately.
validValue.description: Above average social/interpersonal functioning - Good functioning in all social areas, and interpersonally effective. Interested and involved in a wide range of social and interpersonal activities, including both close and casual friends. Age-appropriate involvement in intimate relationships. No more than everyday interpersonal problems or concerns (e.g., an occasional argument with spouse, girlfriend/boyfriend, friends, coworkers, or classmates). Able to resolve such conflicts appropriately.

validValue.meaningText: Superior social/interpersonal functioning - Superior functioning in a wide range of social and interpersonal activities. Frequently seeks out others and has multiple satisfying interpersonal relationships, including multiple close and casual friends. Is sought out by others because of his or her many positive qualities. Age-appropriate involvement in intimate relationships.
validValue.description: Superior social/interpersonal functioning - Superior functioning in a wide range of social and interpersonal activities. Frequently seeks out others and has multiple satisfying interpersonal relationships, including multiple close and casual friends. Is sought out by others because of his or her many positive qualities. Age-appropriate involvement in intimate relationships.

Serious impairment in communication with others (e.g., avoids participating in most social activities).

Serious impairment in relationships with all peers, including acquaintances. Few interactions with family members (e.g., often alone in room). Serious impairment in communication with others (e.g., avoids participating in most social activities).

validValue.meaningText: Major impairment in social and interpersonal functioning - Major impairment in social functioning. Serious impairment in relationships with friends or peers (e.g., very few or no friends, frequent conflicts with friends, or frequently avoids friends). Frequent combative or verbally argumentative behavior with peers. Infrequent contact with family members (e.g., sometimes does not respond to family or avoids family members).
validValue.description: Major impairment in social and interpersonal functioning - Major impairment in social functioning. Serious impairment in relationships with friends or peers (e.g., very few or no friends, frequent conflicts with friends, or frequently avoids friends). Frequent combative or verbally argumentative behavior with peers. Infrequent contact with family members (e.g., sometimes does not respond to family or avoids family members).

validValue.meaningText: Serious impairment in social/interpersonal functioning - Serious impairment in social functioning. No close friends or intimate partner but has some casual social contacts (e.g., acquaintances, school/work friends only). Rarely seeks out others. Occasional combative or verbally argumentative behavior with peers. Beginning to withdraw from family members (e.g., does not initiate conversation with family, but will respond if addressed).
validValue.description: Serious impairment in social/interpersonal functioning - Serious impairment in social functioning. No close friends or intimate partner but has some casual social contacts (e.g., acquaintances, school/work friends only). Rarely seeks out others. Occasional combative or verbally argumentative behavior with peers. Beginning to withdraw from family members (e.g., does not initiate conversation with family, but will respond if addressed).

validValue.meaningText: Moderate impairment in social/interpersonal functioning - Moderate impairment in social functioning. Moderate impairment present (e.g., few close friends; significant but intermittent conflicts with peers, coworkers, or classmates). Moderate difficulty developing age-appropriate intimate relationships (e.g., infrequent dating). Occasionally seeks out others but will respond if invited by others to participate in an activity.
